Award.AwardTitle: NSF-IOS-BSF: Biochemical and genetic basis of salinity tolerance in tilapia
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tilapias are a group of fish with very diverse abilities to tolerate environmental (pH, salinity, pollution) stress and change. This project will compare two tilapia species to decipher the biological mechanisms used by fish (and animals in general) for coping with environmental stress and change. Environmental change represents a global concern and can occur over a range of time scales (daily, annual, decadal etc.) and spatial scales (local, regional, etc.). This project develops and applies novel molecular biology approaches for revealing the mechanisms used by stress-tolerant tilapia, but lacking in stress-sensitive tilapia, for coping with environmental (in particular, salinity) change. This is especially important because tilapia are the most rapidly growing aquaculture commodity world-wide and knowledge about which species to select for increased food production in the developing world is critical. These studies also inform us about the evolutionary time scales needed for these fish, as well as other animals, to adapt to environmental changes. In addition, the project facilitates assessment of the potential for invasiveness if tilapia are cultured in non-native habitats. This project advances education by training of graduate and undergraduate students, including students from minorities that are underrepresented in the sciences. It also provides outreach to K-12 students and educators, aquaculture producers, and conservation organizations. It includes international collaborations and student exchange in Africa and Israel. In addition, this project will generate and make available molecular biology tools and approaches that can be used by researchers in many other areas of biology.

This project tests the overall hypothesis that euryhaline tilapia differ from their stenohaline congeners by salinity-induced regulation of specific mRNAs and proteins that are necessary for high osmotolerance/ salinity tolerance. The focus will be on previously identified osmoregulatory proteins, myo-inositol phosphate synthase (MIPS), inositol monophosphatase 1 (IMAP1), and the Na-K ATPase alpha 3 subunit (NKA3a), to reveal causality between the regulation of these genes and salinity tolerance. Objective 1 is to determine mRNAs and proteins that are altered by salinity in euryhaline tilapia (Oreochromis mossambicus) compared to a congeneric stenohaline species, O. niloticus. This objective includes comparison of salinity effects on mRNA and protein abundances and identification of relevant single amino acid variants (SAVs) and post-translational modifications. Objective 2 is to reveal inducible cis-elements in euryhaline tilapia using a combination of experimental (enhancer trapping) and bioinformatics (motif searching) approaches. Objective 3 is to purify the transcription factor that activates the tilapia osmotically/salinity responsive enhancer in IMPA1 and MIPS genes by affinity-based, functional complementation, and mass spectrometry approaches. Objective 4 comprises genome editing in tilapia cells to determine whether MIPS and IMPA1 genes, and the NKA3a SAV A428?Â¨S are necessary for maintaining high cellular osmotolerance. Effects on cellular phenotype will be assessed by cell morphology/ proliferation assays, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics. Objective 5 is to perform genome editing of a target informed by Objective 4 in whole tilapia. Effects on tilapia salinity tolerance, morphology, behavior, physiology and molecular phenotypes (transcriptome, proteome, metabolome) will be analyzed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims at understanding the mechanistic basis for high salinity tolerance in fish. Tilapia, which are African cichlids that have repidly evolved into many different species, were the main model for this research. Tilapia are economically broadly relevant as the second most important group of aqauculture fish (second only to carps). Therefore, aquaculture and fisheries science benefit from this project. Tilapia are cultivated as a food-source globally, and knowing why some species are more hardy and likely to survive environmental fluctuations aids in increasing food production in a changing climate. The project represents a key component of a concerted collaborative effort that was conducted jointly with the laboratory of Dr. Avner Cnaani (ARO, Israel). 

In fishes, salinity challenges will only become more ecologically relevant as changes to atmospheric temperature alter the intensity of the global water cycle. Fishes inhabiting hypersaline lakes, such as Mozambique tilapia, will be most affected by these changes. Hypersaline lakes often lack an outflow river because they do not exceed full capacity of water. As a result, precipitation and evaporation largely determine the salinity of the water body. Therefore, as the atmosphere continues to warm, the salinity of hypersaline lakes will fluctuate more dramatically in the future. In addition to the importance of tilapia for aqauculture, their high environmental stress tolerance makes them highly invasive and mitigation of their invasiveness requires significant managment efforts and resources.

The hypothesis addressed in this project was that euryhaline tilapia differ from stenohaline tilapia by salinity-induced regulation of specific mRNAs and proteins that are necessary for high salinity tolerance (through control of compatible organic osmolyte levels and other effector mechanisms). Furthermore, differential regulation of these mRNAs and proteins in euryhaline versus stenohaline tilapia was hypothesized to be a result of genetic differences in regulatory factors that were identified in this project. We have tested this hypothesis and proven that it is correct by showing that transcriptome responses (mRNA expression) and proteome responses (protein expression) to salinity stress are much more pronounced and involve many more components in multiple tissues of eurhaline (Mozambique) tilapia compared to  stenohaline (Nile) tilapia.

We have also shown that these salinity-regulated changes in gene and protein expression are controlled by specific regulatory enhancer elements in the promoter of osmregulated genes (OSRE1 and others). Furthermore, this project has generated new knowledge of the signaling pathways that are involved in the activation of osmoregulated genes in fish. We have identified the transcription factors involved in this process and also several upstream regulators of these transcription factors. 

Our project also advanced insight into the question of possible interplay between genetic (adaptive) enhancer (and the corresponding transcription factor) evolution and the role of epigenetic marks for rapid adaptation to environmental stress. These concerted mechanisms have been described as "assisted evolution" because epigenetic marks imposed by environmental conditions can lead to increased mutations in targeted locations of the genome and therefore facilitate faster evolution in those regions. This project has identified hundreds of such epigenetic marks as specific histone posttranslational modifications in multiple tilapia cells and tissues.

SIgnificant new resources that are of broad interest to the scientific comunity have been developed, including a high-throughput gene editing method for fish cells, fish cell lines, knockout tilapia, a very elaborate repertoire of resources for high-precision, quantitative proteomics approaches that are amenable for field studies and physiological/ evolutionary ecology, and novel plasmids and DNA sequences.

This project supported many graduate and undergraduate students during the COVID19 pandemic by providing a means to engage in socially distanced, safe, and meaningful lab work and hands-on activities. Graduate students have acquired mentoring skills by supervising undergraduate interns, which is an important part in their professional development. 

Numerous peer-reviewed scientific articles were published and formal presentations contributed at scientific conferences to disseminate the results of this project. As many of these presentations were virtual due to SARS-CoV-2 restrictions, presentations were recorded and uploaded for public use on video-hosting websites, such asYouTube. Undergraduate students have presented posters reporting work from this project at the UC Davis Undergraduate Research Conference and talks at National conferences.
